fields.description:
# I started my OnDemand instance.
# (BUG) Even though there is an application link between JIRA and Bamboo there is no gadgets display. 
# I then added an application link to another JIRA server. The gadgets display.
# I added a gadget to my dashboard.
# I restarted JIRA.
# (BUG) After the restart all the bamboo gadgets are gone again.
fields.summary: The bamboo gadgets do not seem to display after a restart (in OnDemand?)

fields.description:
Definition of Done:
Add a new tab to the agent view (see screenshot)
Ensure capability changes are audited & displayed in the agent's audit log
Ensure enabling / disabling of agent is audited & displayed in the agent's audit log

Originally raised by [~pleschev]
https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/BUILDENG-3005

Related issues:
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-11577
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-3636
fields.summary: Add agent audit logging to Bamboo

fields.description:
Testing for a problem regarding using the wrapper to run Bamboo on Linux- the SAC ticket link is attached-we downloaded a TAR.GZ and TGZ archive packages of Bamboo 4.4.3 and installed them on two seperate machines. 

1. The executable file has a different name in each package. In the TAR.GZ it's called bamboo-start, in TGZ it's called run-bamboo

2. When running the bamboo-start on my machine I get the following error:

{code}
[sepideh@kidney wrapper]$ ls -l
total 132
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root   4096 Feb 19 11:44 lib
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  14997 Feb 19 11:39 start-bamboo
-rwxrwxrwx 1 root root 113407 Feb 19 11:39 wrapper
[sepideh@kidney wrapper]$ sudo ./start-bamboo start
[sudo] password for sepideh:
Starting Bamboo Continuous Integration Server...
./start-bamboo: line 405: /media/applications/sepideh/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.3/wrapper/wrapper: No such file or directory
{code}

And running the run-bamboo file ends up with this error: 
{code}
armen@ubuntu:~/Documents/Bamboo4.4.3/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.3/wrapper$ ls -al
total 480
drwxr-xr-x 3 armen armen   4096 2013-02-19 11:42 .
drwxr-xr-x 9 armen armen   4096 2013-02-19 11:42 ..
drwxr-xr-x 2 armen armen   4096 2013-02-19 11:42 lib
-rwxr-xr-x 1 armen armen  15099 2013-02-19 11:39 run-bamboo
-rwxr-xr-x 1 armen armen 462368 2013-02-19 11:39 wrapper
armen@ubuntu:~/Documents/Bamboo4.4.3/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.3/wrapper$ sudo ./run-bamboo start
Starting Bamboo Continuous Integration Server...
/home/armen/Documents/Bamboo4.4.3/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.3/wrapper/wrapper: 1: Syntax error: "(" unexpected
armen@ubuntu:~/Documents/Bamboo4.4.3/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.3/wrapper$ 
{code}

*We were able to run Bamboo with the .sh file on both machines.
fields.summary: Problem running Bamboo via the wrapper on Linux

fields.description: With the last release the Details section hides the Agent field and provides 'Show More' to see all details.   It displays Labels even though there are none defined.  This is a step backwards for our team, we frequently uses the Agent field - need a way to disable this feature or specific which fields are displayed / hidden by default.
fields.summary: Build Result Summary Details hides frequently used fields

fields.description: Support and bundle the SBT Task plugin for OnDemand
fields.summary: Bundle Bamboo SBT Task plugin

fields.description:
Currently, the Branch Updater and Gatekeepr merging capabilities are hard wired to the Plan Configuration/Branches page. These merging mechanisms should be available as tasks under the plan jobs section. 

This would allow a build job to:
# control when merging occurs
# perform possibly multiple merges
# initiate merging as a manual task after other tasks have completed 
# execute error response tasks on merge failure. 

In short, I need more control over merging than the hard-wired mechanisms. I need the ability to implement change flow between branches and between repositories and designated places within the software construction process. I like CI merging however the current bamboo merge mechanisms are too limiting.
fields.summary: Allow branch merging to be executed as tasks rather than Plan Configuration/Branches policy

fields.description:
I want a scenario where builds are automatically started when a (Git) commit is pushed to master, but I don't want any automatic builds when commits are pushed to branchs.  But I want auto-branch creation so developers don't have to create the branches themselves.

So, I've set auto-create branches to be true, and I changed the build trigger to "Repository triggers the build when changes are committed".  I've added the Git post-receive trigger so that it checks each commit and only sends a build request to Bamboo if the commit goes on the master branch.  This all seems to work fine and my builds do get run properly when I commit to master.

However, I ALSO appear to get builds running when a branch is first created/pushed to the Git repository.  This is very annoying because we use a lot of branches and building them when they are created, rather than waiting for something interesting and correct to be pushed to the branch, means we have a lot of worthless builds.

It doesn't seem right to me that newly-created branches are built immediately, and it especially doesn't seem right if I've set the trigger type to "Repository triggers the build", since my triggers did NOT start a build in this case.
fields.summary: Set "Repository triggers the build" but builds still happen automatically on every branch create

fields.description:
I am using confluence to document acceptance criteria for a specific feature and want to cross reference each acceptance criteria with the functional test case/method that tests it.

Of course I can simply put the test names next to the acceptance criteria (thats what I'm doing no), but it would be much better to i) link to latest run of the test (seems this isn't possible currently) ii) Have confluence show the test name in red/green depending on if the test in question passed in the last run or not.
fields.summary: Ability to link to latest version of a specific test case or method.

fields.description:
We are using perforce workspaces for all of our plans.
After upgrading to 4.3.2 we experience that all workspaces 
are cleaned:

05-Mar-2013 22:05:34	Build MARDP-CMBATCHV0403-HR-457 started building on agent MARDT-rus-bbag01.corp.gds.jeppesen.com-1-WIN64

05-Mar-2013 22:05:38	Build working directory is c:\views\md_CmBatch_v04.3_bb_ci_rusbbag01
05-Mar-2013 22:05:38	Cleaning directory c:\views\md_CmBatch_v04.3_bb_ci_rusbbag01


This is a big problem for us. Any way to prevent it?

BR
Stefan
fields.summary: After upgrade to Bamboo 4.3.2 all workspaces cleaned
Html escaped twice for the log entry

fields.description: Bamboo Activity stream in JIRA does not display the branch icon where it should be. They style is: {code}{code} But icon is missing (see attachment). JIRA: 5.2.6 Bamboo: 4.4.1 Plugin: bundled
fields.summary: Bamboo Activity stream in JIRA does not display the branch icon

fields.description: If the checkout task includes a branch in a repository that does not exist (someone forgot to make it, mispelled it etc...) I would like the checkout task to fail instead of reporting it as a system error.
fields.summary: If a repository branch does not exist the checkout task should fail instead of the HG error reporting as a system error

fields.description:
*Problem*
In Bamboo version 4.4.0 and 4.4.4, the Remove Artifacts button does not work.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Create a simple Script Task in the job, like this:
{noformat}
echo "Hello" > artifact.txt
{noformat}
# Create an artifact definition, like this:
{noformat}
Name: test
Location: <empty>
Copy Pattern: artifact.txt
{noformat}
# Run the plan
# The file will be created at {{BAMBOO_HOME\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1\artifact.txt}}
# Go to the build results page, Artifacts tab, and click "Remove Artifacts".
# The requests to delete the artifacts can be seen in the logs:
{noformat}
2013-03-20 11:00:20,589 INFO [qtp2026789660-134] [AccessLogFilter] admin POST http://localhost:8085/chain/result/removeChainArtifacts.action 63752kb
2013-03-20 11:00:20,615 DEBUG [qtp2026789660-134] [AccessLogFilter] END: admin POST http://localhost:8085/chain/result/removeChainArtifacts.action 63752kb-880kb 26ms
2013-03-20 11:00:20,624 INFO [qtp2026789660-132] [AccessLogFilter] admin POST http://localhost:8085/chain/result/removeChainArtifacts.action 62870kb
2013-03-20 11:00:20,732 DEBUG [qtp2026789660-132] [AccessLogFilter] END: admin POST http://localhost:8085/chain/result/removeChainArtifacts.action 62870kb-2956kb 108ms
{noformat}
# But the artifact can still be found at {{BAMBOO_HOME\xml-data\build-dir\PROJ-PLAN-JOB1\artifact.txt}}.
fields.summary: Remove Artifacts button does not work

fields.description:
As a bamboo admin, I would like the value of a password within a commandline to be masked in the metadata view.

Steps to reproduce:
# Create a global or plan variable which contains the string 'password' (in my example 'libraryPassword')
# Create a script/commandline task with a commandline containing a reference to the plan variable, ${bamboo.libraryPassword}
# Start a build.
# Open the metadata view.

The password is shown in it's unmasked version as part of the commandline, but masked on every other place (logs and the variable itself).


My work around for now is to create a second script which reads the variable as a environment variable and calls the first script.

As a new user to bamboo, this security flaw is not obvious, certianly not when the variable settings page states that any variable containing the string 'password' will be masked.
fields.summary: Mask passwords in script task commandline

fields.description:
Hello,

Since our pre-loaded Elastic Bamboo AMI still uses Amazon Linux AMI 2011.09, some customers are reporting problems to install new packages necessary for the desired Bamboo tasks (tests, builds, etc.).

Please verify the possibility to create newer AMIs with a newer version of Amazon Linux, supporting a most recent kernel and libraries.
fields.summary: New Amazon Linux version on Elastic Bamboo AMI

fields.description:
In the new TestNG result parser they are not failing the build if setup test methods fail (i.e. those marked as is-config=”true”).  We should be able to fail the build if setup methods fail.

Also, they are not reporting the number of skipped tests; just a lower number of passed test.  This can make it difficult to tell when things go wrong in a build.
fields.summary: TestNG Result parser is not failing the build if setup test methods fail

fields.description:
Hi, several of our teams are now deploying products to Android, and as you can imagine that means working with Android Git forests...and the repo command.

All good, except that using the repo command completely hides the source code checkout etc from Bamboo, which means you lose all the ALM like features, getting JIRA references from commit logs, being able to see what source deltas go into a build and the testing etc, etc. Not good.

In addition, in tools like Crucible, we can't add 300 git repos to a Crucible project...well we can but obviously this gives Crucible indigestion. Plus, even if we limit the forest to a few key git repos, linked to the Crucible project, Crucible is still not able to anchor patches properly.

This is ultimate a problem in JIRA as well. You can manually sustain 300 app links to the 300 git repos in an Android forest.

The atlassian tools as a whole, need a completely new feature for dealing with a group of source code repos or a "forest". So that we can point Bamboo, or Crucible or JIRA to an Android style forest of Git repos and expect the tools to do something reasonable.

I'm guessing other companies are running into this sort of thing as well, I see this as an important feature for Atlsasian to be part of the Android develpment environment.

You can find out more about the repo command here:

[http://source.android.com/source/version-control.html]
fields.summary: Support Android style Git forrests

fields.description:
Have defined a plan that has 3 stages, with the 3rd stage being defined as "manual".  For the 3rd stage, I only created the stage, but no jobs in it (I was still thinking how to organize the build).  Eventually, a day later, I decided to remove that 3rd stage in favor of creating a new plan.  When I went to delete the stage, after pressing "Confirm", the UI returned showing the stage was still there.  When attempting to delete it again, received error message saying that the stage does not exist.

Hitting Refresh in the browser while on the plan configuration page was still stubbornly showing the deleted stage.
fields.summary: Delete stage not reflected in UI

fields.description:
Hi,

We have had this error a lot recently, problem is that I have no clue how to resolve this. I attached the bamboo log which you can hopefully use to find the source of the isse.

This is the full error:
Build M20122R-TEST-BUILD-202 had to be cancelled: it was marked as queued but was not present in the queue for (at least) the past 720 seconds.

The result of the error is that the building stops and the plan fails. It seems as if the job is running but the output is not visible in the logs view while the plan is running.

thanks!
fields.summary: Build had to be cancelled: it was marked as queued but was not present in the queue for (at least) the past 720 seconds.

fields.description: Job failed because a global variable was not set correctly. Fixed the variable and then choose the "Rerun failed/incomplete jobs only". Looks like it is still using the old value. I double checked this a few times.
fields.summary: Variable not updated on rerun failed jobs

fields.description:
Reported on JDK 6, Polish Windows 8 64bit.
{noformat}
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.text.SimpleDateFormat.matchZoneString(SimpleDateFormat.java:1452)
	at java.text.SimpleDateFormat.subParseZoneString(SimpleDateFormat.java:1502)
	at java.text.SimpleDateFormat.subParse(SimpleDateFormat.java:1850)
	at java.text.SimpleDateFormat.parse(SimpleDateFormat.java:1311)
	at java.text.DateFormat.parse(DateFormat.java:335)
	at com.thoughtworks.xstream.core.JVM.<clinit>(JVM.java:78)
{noformat}

It seems that the list of zones given to JDK by the OS is unexpectedly short and this causes the exception.
An upgrade to JDK 7 fixed this problem (possibly, an upgrade to the latest JDK 6 will fix it too).
fields.summary: Bamboo does not start due to NullPointerException in SimpleDateFormat

fields.description:
It would be great to have a 'Delete All' button on the History tab of a build plan to delete all the history entries manually.

Even nicer would be the ability to flag several of them and have a button to delete all entries flagged.

We often find ourselves in the scenario where we want to clean up several entries at once, clicking them one by one consumes a lot of time.
fields.summary: Ability to perform ad-hoc bulk deletion of build history

fields.description:
This problem is related to automatic branch management and git fetch/merge/commit.

When a new commit is detected in a plan branch, Bamboo queues it for a build. What exactly remembered by Bamboo to checkout - branch name (as it is configured and supposed to be) or explicit commit in this branch?

The problem is following (as illustrated on the attached image, timeline is up to down):

- You have few branch plans configured as Gatekeepers for an integration branch (let's call it next).
- Developer A pushes his changes into personal branch, Bamboo checkouts next (X), merges A's changes into it, and starts building it (X+A).
- While it is building, Developer B does the same for his branch, and build B is queued.
- After the plan A completes, Bamboo pushes updated integration branch (next) to Gitolite server (X+A to Y, fast forward).
- Bamboo takes queued build B and checkouts integration branch (next) to do the same.

The problem is that on that step Bamboo 4.4.0 checkouts not NEW state of the integration branch with just pushed changes (Y on the image to build Y+B), but that commit in the next which was last when the build B was queued (X). As result, it attempts to push back non fast-forward updates (X+B), and since they are disabled on Gitolite, the push fails. In fact, this makes impossible to use this feature because too many pushes fail if you have active committers.

As I understand, it should checkout next by the branch name to its current state with just pushed updates, not an older commit (we configure branch by name, not a single commit). Then there will be no such problem since all commits into the integration branch will be fast-forward.

In short, it should be:
X+A -> Y (fast forward)
Y+B -> Z (fast forward)
And only Bamboo updates next branch, that guarantees FF only updates.

Currently it is:
X+A -> Y (fast forward)
X+B -> Z (non fast forward, FAILS)
X is chosen because it was last when B was detected and build queued. But we should merge with next branch (its HEAD), not with some commit in the past.
fields.summary: Wrong commits are checked out using Gatekeeper auto-merging

fields.description:
I am logging this request as Bamboo administrator of OpenSource project. SEN can be provided on request.

Being running few remote agents, we often have cases when git fetch or push fails or is slow (using ssh keys and gitolite on the other end). It does not depend on Internet channels, I replicated that even within local test installation and LAN (really with 3 VMs running on VMware ESXi server and no external networks).

One case: fetch is slow and unreliable.
Other case: using auto-merge configuration, it can't push merged branch back to gitolite with 50% probability:

{code}Push command error: Warning: Permanently added '[127.0.0.1]:60287' (RSA) to the list of known hosts.
error: unpack failed: eof before pack header was fully read
To ssh://d09ed13d-78e9-44c2-bc33-359a5f1f189f@127.0.0.1:60287/project.git
 ! [remote rejected] next -> next (n/a (unpacker error))
error: failed to push some refs to 'ssh://d09ed13d-78e9-44c2-bc33-359a5f1f189f@127.0.0.1:60287/project.git'{code}

After patching the git plugin to bypass ssh proxy and using agent's ssh key directly, both problems were solved.

So I would like to have new options:
- to bypass the proxy channel completely;
- to pass passwords/keys to selected agents to allow them to auth to gitolite directly.

The 1st case probably will work if we set AuthenticationType=None.
The 2nd one should pass keys or passwords to agents using encrypted channel, authenticate to remote system and drop them not storing to agent's file system.
fields.summary: New options to bypass git ssh proxy channel

fields.description:
http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/latest/com/atlassian/bamboo/task/TaskResultBuilder.html

In the current Javadoc for TaskResultBuilder.copyWithNewState it states "Coppies a taskResult and changes the state". Seems to be 1 too many P's there. Should be "Copies a taskResult and changes the state"
fields.summary: Minor Typo in Javadoc for TaskResultBuilder.copyWithNewState method

fields.description:
SVN server hosted on an SNI enabled webserver, the import of maven project fails with the below NPE 
{noformat}
2013-02-27 19:26:37,972 ERROR [ajp-bio-127.0.0.1-7979-exec-19] [BambooPluginUtils] Failed to validate build configuration for the Subversion repository (com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.system.repository:svn).
java.lang.NullPointerException
at sun.security.ssl.JsseJce.isEcAvailable(JsseJce.java:183)
at sun.security.ssl.CipherSuite$KeyExchange.isAvailable(CipherSuite.java:297)
at sun.security.ssl.CipherSuite.isAvailable(CipherSuite.java:162)
at sun.security.ssl.CipherSuiteList.<init>(CipherSuiteList.java:87)
at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.setEnabledCipherSuites(SSLSocketImpl.java:2086)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.util.SVNSocketFactory.configureSSLSocket(SVNSocketFactory.java:270)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.util.SVNSocketFactory.createSSLSocket(SVNSocketFactory.java:91)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.http.HTTPConnection.connect(HTTPConnection.java:268)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.http.HTTPConnection.request(HTTPConnection.java:419)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.http.HTTPConnection.request(HTTPConnection.java:362)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.http.HTTPConnection.request(HTTPConnection.java:350)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVConnection.performHttpRequest(DAVConnection.java:708)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVConnection.exchangeCapabilities(DAVConnection.java:628)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVConnection.open(DAVConnection.java:103)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVRepository.openConnection(DAVRepository.java:1016)
at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.dav.DAVRepository.testConnection(DAVRepository.java:99)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SvnRepository.validate(SvnRepository.java:1021)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.creation.RepositoryConfigHelper$2.call(RepositoryConfigHelper.java:142)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.creation.RepositoryConfigHelper$2.call(RepositoryConfigHelper.java:138)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.BambooPluginUtils.callUnsafeCode(BambooPluginUtils.java:82)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.creation.RepositoryConfigHelper.validateConfig(RepositoryConfigHelper.java:135)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.admin.ImportMavenPlanCheckoutPomAction.validate(ImportMavenPlanCheckoutPomAction.java:72)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.interceptor.DefaultWorkflowInterceptor.doIntercept(DefaultWorkflowInterceptor.java:154)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooWorkflowInterceptor.validateWorkflow(BambooWorkflowInterceptor.java:53)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooWorkflowInterceptor.access$000(BambooWorkflowInterceptor.java:16)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooWorkflowInterceptor$1.call(BambooWorkflowInterceptor.java:33)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooWorkflowInterceptor$1.call(BambooWorkflowInterceptor.java:29)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.BambooProfilingUtils.withUtilTimerStack(BambooProfilingUtils.java:49)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooWorkflowInterceptor.doIntercept(BambooWorkflowInterceptor.java:28)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.interceptor.MethodFilterInterceptor.intercept(MethodFilterInterceptor.java:86)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:190)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.validator.ValidationInterceptor.doIntercept(ValidationInterceptor.java:116)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooValidationInterceptor.validate(BambooValidationInterceptor.java:48)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooValidationInterceptor.access$000(BambooValidationInterceptor.java:12)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooValidationInterceptor$1.call(BambooValidationInterceptor.java:28)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooValidationInterceptor$1.call(BambooValidationInterceptor.java:24)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.BambooProfilingUtils.withUtilTimerStack(BambooProfilingUtils.java:49)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.BambooValidationInterceptor.doIntercept(BambooValidationInterceptor.java:23)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.interceptor.MethodFilterInterceptor.intercept(MethodFilterInterceptor.java:86)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:190)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.FieldErrorUsageVerifier.intercept(FieldErrorUsageVerifier.java:48)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:190)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.JSONValidationInterceptor.doIntercept(JSONValidationInterceptor.java:69)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.AbstractBambooInterceptor$1.call(AbstractBambooInterceptor.java:36)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.AbstractBambooInterceptor$1.call(AbstractBambooInterceptor.java:32)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.BambooProfilingUtils.withUtilTimerStack(BambooProfilingUtils.java:49)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.AbstractBambooInterceptor.intercept(AbstractBambooInterceptor.java:31)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:190)
at com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.interceptors.SimpleConversionErrorInterceptor.intercept(SimpleConversionErrorInterceptor.java:78)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:190)
at com.opensymphony.xwork.interceptor.AroundInterceptor.intercept(AroundInterceptor.java:31)
{noformat}

This is related to the fact that SNI requires TLSv1 and the svnkit supports only the TLSv3 based on the code svnkit code: http://svn.svnkit.com/repos/svnkit/branches/1.3.x/svnkit/src/main/java/org/tmatesoft/svn/core/internal/util/SVNSocketFactory.java

Because of this bug in svnkit and the fact that this exception is not handled in bamboo, we have a looping situation that causes Bamboo to hang.

*Workaround*
The workaround is to start Bamboo with the property -Dsvnkit.http.sslProtocols=TLSv1
fields.summary: SVN server hosted on an SNI enabled webserver throws NPE during operations like maven import

fields.description:
I have my JUnit reports at 
<bamboo-home>\xml-data\build-dir\TCLOUD-UT-SUT\test-results

I am using JUnit Parser task with the report location specified as **/test-results/*.xml......I have tried giving exact file name too & other otions also. The task always fails with a message in the log

failing task because test cases were expected but none found

I am attaching the JUnit report file. 

I think it's a bug.
fields.summary: Bamboo not recognising JUnit report

fields.description:
64-bit wrapper is supported on Linux, but it is properly configured in the agent only. I created a KB for it for the customers that need help configuring it on their 64-bit linux servers: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/How+to+configure+Bamboo+Java+service+wrapper+on+64+bit+Linux
and we will hopefully have more information about it in our documents.
But, is there a way to have it included in the package and supported on 64-bit Linux environments to avoid the workaround?
fields.summary: Avoiding the "Workaround" for Java service wrapper on 64-bit Linux

fields.description:
When executing under Maven 3.x with parallel build (-T 1C), a warning appears saying that bamboo-artifact-sharing-maven-plugin is unknown to be threadsafe.

To avoid potential errors, the @threadSafe annotation has to be added to the plugin, with the value being true/false as appropriate. That way, customers will know for sure whether the plugin is thread safe or not.
fields.summary: Clarify whether the artifact sharing plugin is thread safe

fields.description:
I am manually copying build plans from bamboo 2.6.3 to bamboo 4.4. I used to have a project key named "21" for our 2.1 release. When I try to use "21" as a project key in bamboo 4.4, I get the error:
"A project key must consist of 2 or more upper case alphanumeric characters."
if I am not mistaken, "21" is "2 or more upper case alphanumeric characters".
So I guess this is a bug and I will just use a different key (and find all the artifact URLs used around here and get them changed to)
fields.summary: Error message for key validation is incorrect

fields.description:
Allowing bamboo to support multiple instances of Xcode would be a fantastic feature within the iOS/Cocoa and Xcode Support plugin for Bamboo, and would greatly expand the abilities for Bamboo support on Mac.

A user can download multiple versions of xcode and install by simply extracting to a unique folder for each.  Making bamboo aware of the location of each xcode installation, the plugin could execute the "xcode-select -switch" or "xcode-switch" using sudo to actually set the instance of xcode used by the build.  The user may need to setup sudo permissions on the command invoked by the userid running the agent beforehand, otherwise storing an encrypted password for the account would be advisable, since the command needs to be run as an admin.

A drawback of this would be restricting to one build (or one agent) on the Mac at a time, as changing the version of xcode while another build runs would cause issues.
fields.summary: As a bamboo xcode plugin user, I would like support for multiple instances of xcode

fields.description:
When configuring the subversion client, you are given 3 options for authentication:

- Password
- SSH
- SSL Certificate

All three of these options override the default subversion configuration, which in our case is already configured with digital certificates out the box and already works.

What is missing is a fourth option:

- Default

This fourth option should simple leave svnkit to it's default behaviour, which is to respect the native subversion configuration on the agent itself.

The impact of this bug is that we have to manually enter the path and passphrase to the certificate in the Bamboo UI for every single plan, which is painful (we have many plans).
fields.summary: subversion client has no support for default subversion authentication

fields.description: As a user of e.g. the SCP command, I would like to have a more granular access to the buildTime than the ISO 8601 format. Ideally, there are additional variables like bamboo.buildYear, bamboo.BuildMonth, ... that may then be used in the SCP target file name or similar places.
fields.summary: Provide more global variables for components of bamboo.buildTime

fields.description: "My" branch would be identified by the author of last commit to the branch. If the last author is mappable to user making the REST call, then the branch is "mine"
fields.summary: let user retrieve "my" plan branches using REST

fields.description:
Presently Bamboo comes bundled with the svnkit library in to Bamboo which has some limitations compared with the subversion client

{quote}
Things that are broken in svnkit that work in subversion:

- SSL support in svnkit has bugs, like the TLS protocol bug that triggers the infinite loop bug BSP-9391.
- Svnkit only supported SNI since two weeks ago, and only on Java 7. In contrast, subversion handles SNI out the box.
- Bamboo's use of svnkit forces people to enter the passphrase of the bamboo SSL client certificate on every plan configuration. Native subversion lets you set this up and have all jobs "just work" with no external messing about with authn or authz at all. (To be fair svnkit allows this default bahviour too, Bamboo chooses not to support it and always overrides the svnkit default behaviour).
{quote}

It would be great to have one similar to the way that Bamboo allows for both jgit and native git clients.
fields.summary: Add support for native subversion clients

fields.description:
Hi, 
we have the problem, that remote agent links on <server>/bamboo/agent/viewAgents.action always have the admin url

locale agent link on page:
<server>/bamboo/agent/viewAgent.action?agentId=12345

remote agent link on page:
<server>/bamboo/admin/agent/viewAgent.action?agentId=54321

Jochen

fields.description: When using the shared repositories feature, the list of repositories fails to load at times. The error that is shown comes from Bamboo's own API, thereby hiding the actual error from Bitbucket. For example, if you get an empty list of repositories from the API call, you get a 500 from the Bamboo API instead of something like "Received an empty list of repositories". Or the even more generic "400 Bad request" which makes troubleshooting quite difficult, especially in OnDemand versions.
fields.summary: Give more meaningful errors when encountering trouble loading Bitbucket data

fields.description: If I quarantine the tests which failed a build I'd like the build to turn green. As a workaround I can re-run failed jobs to get the expected result.

Please add a feature to facilitate the job requirement management (adding or removing) for a lot of jobs.

fields.description:
Refer to this Answers thread : https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/84968/bamboo-remote-agent-capability-auto-detection

It seems the flag -DDISABLE_AGENT_AUTO_CAPABILITY_DETECTION=true can be specified at the Bamboo SERVER's wrapper.conf file to disable auto-detection of capabilities on remote agents for all agents on that server.

For organizations running many agents 25-100 it would be VERY useful to allow this flag to work at each unique AGENT level in the agent's wrapper.conf file. Running 100 agents we have teams who want the capability auto-detection and do not want to manage the capabilities at all; and also teams who want explicit control of specifying their agents' capabilities using a bamboo-capabilities.properties file. It seems that if the agent allows the use of an agent-side bamboo-capabilities.properties file then it should also allow use of the DISABLE_AGENT_AUTO_CAPABILITY_DETECTION flag, or else what is the point of the bamboo-capabilities.properties file?

h4. Duplication Steps
* Directions in, [Additional remote agent options|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Additional+remote+agent+options#Additionalremoteagentoptions-Disablingauto-capabilitydetectionfortheremoteagent], do not work as expected. Auto-detection still occurs.
fields.summary: Disable Capability Auto-Detection at the Remote Agent-Level not functioning

How will the efficiency of a Best Practice process be measured? Can the advantages of a BP process be quantified? What sort of metrics can be employed? Where does one organisation's Best Practice turn into another's voguish nightmare?

fields.summary: Configuration example for Maven dependency processor task

fields.description:
If a user checks creates a new branch called "feature-1" and we need all 3 repositories to be checked out into the "feature-1" branch we can't do it with automatic branching.

{noformat}
Repository | Branch
-------------------------------------------------

PROJECT    default     o--------------o
                        \            / 
           feature-1     o--o-o--o--o

TESTING    default     o--------------o
                        \            / 
           feature-1     o----------o


DEPLOY     default     o--------------o
                        \            / 
           feature-1     o-------o--o
{noformat}

We can have three separate jobs: Project/Testing/Deploy but it's not possible to clone three separate repositories to the same job in the same plan using automatic branching.
fields.summary: Being able to clone multiple separate repositories to the same branch in the same job

fields.description: If a user has an alias with the greater than symbol such as *sultan <sultan@example.com>* then the > symbol is replaced with > when viewing the issue details from this page {{/browse/user/<user_name>}}
fields.summary: Replace > with > in the user detaails page

fields.description: In the Dashboard area (My Bamboo, All Plans, Current Activity) there exists the big Wallboards icon and dropdown menu. From what I've seen and from an Atlassian response on Answer : https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/139244/bamboo-wallboards-extension there doesn't seem to be an plugin point to add menu items to the Wallboards dropdown. Working with internal Agile teams in my company there has been significant growing demand for many different types of Wallboards displaying all kinds of Bamboo data. Right now someone would have to add a link next to the Current Activity menu that displays a page listing all the Wallboards they have created. This looks very duplicative since there is a big Wallboard icon/dropdown visible as well. It would help keep the UI much cleaner if the Wallboard dropdown allowed plugin points.
fields.summary: Wallboard Plugin Point Needed

fields.description: Identify requirements overview for in scope and out of scope stories. Though an idea of scope already exists, this activity will also be informed by the research activities.
fields.summary: Specification - Best practice broad requirements and scope

fields.description:
Improve JavaDoc for ResultsSummaryManager methods getLatestFailedResultSummaries and getLatestResultSummaries.

The Javadoc published for these methods says : 

"Retrieve list of failed build results (for all builds) in the last few days (number of days is specified in the DAO) This method is filtered to remove results that user doesn't have permission to see"

and

"Retrieve list of build results (for all builds) in the last few days (number of days is specified in the DAO) This method is filtered to remove results that user doesn't have permission to see"

respectively...

Both these definitions say "(number of days is specified in the DAO)". Since the methods don't take a parameter the phrase "(number of days is specified in the DAO)" is awfully vague and confusing. To understand how this method works you need to trace through a variety of classes interfaces to find the actual DAO it references. 

If you don't have access to the source and are writing a plugin this is very confusing. I would suggest just adding the number or at least documenting here the constant used to represent the number.
fields.summary: Improve JavaDoc for ResultsSummaryManager methods getLatestFailedResultSummaries and getLatestResultSummaries

fields.description:
I recently noticed if I go to the Admin area and the System Information page, it shows the Instance Statistics section which lists number of plans and number of builds. The field for Number of Plans seems to be displaying an incorrect number. 

In a brand new fresh install of Bamboo 4.4.0 I created 3 empty Plans. The Stats section then reports 3 Plans as expected. However if I edit a Plan and add 4 JOBS to the existing Default Stage, the Stats section now reports 7 Plans. 

The incorrect number seems to be fed from DefaultSystemStatisticsBean.getNumberOfPlans which calls PlanManager.getPlanCount


If the field is labelled "Number of Plans" it should reflect the actual number of Plans, not Jobs in Stages.
fields.summary: Number of Plans in Admin > System Info area Reports Wrong # of Plans

fields.description:
Some customer ask us for the minimal requirements to install Bamboo (we talk about OS and JVM but not about memory or CPU speed requirement).

- Examples:
 - https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+remote+agent+installation+guide
- https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+installation+guide#Bambooinstallationguide-requirements1.Checkthesystemrequirements
fields.summary: Missing system requirements on Installation Guides.

fields.description:
As per the issue description, the issue can be replicated when anonymous access has been revoked from both global and plan level permissions. After that, any triggers will fail and trying to do a manual test by running the wget command fail with 302 code as below:
{code}

C:\Program Files (x86)\GnuWin32\bin>wget --timeout=10 -t1 http://localhost:10440/bamboo44/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey=TESTA-TSTA
SYSTEM_WGETRC = c:/progra~1/wget/etc/wgetrc
syswgetrc = C:\Program Files (x86)\GnuWin32/etc/wgetrc
--2013-02-22 18:25:04--  http://localhost:10440/bamboo44/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey=TESTA-TSTA
Resolving localhost... 127.0.0.1, ::1
Connecting to localhost|127.0.0.1|:10440... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 302 Found
Location: http://localhost:10440/bamboo44/userlogin!default.action;jsessionid=191ud808wgqik101mmdsvq2yw4?os_destination=%2FupdateAndBuild.action%3FbuildKey%3DTESTA-TSTA [following]
--2013-02-22 18:25:04--  http://localhost:10440/bamboo44/userlogin!default.action;jsessionid=191ud808wgqik101mmdsvq2yw4?os_destination=%2FupdateAndBuild.action%3FbuildKey%3DTESTA-TSTA
Reusing existing connection to localhost:10440.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK
Length: unspecified [text/html]
Saving to: `userlogin!default.action;jsessionid=191ud808wgqik101mmdsvq2yw4@os_destination=%2FupdateAndBuild.action%3FbuildKey=TESTA-TSTA'

    [ <=>                                                                                                                                                           ] 10,073      --.-K/s   in 0s

2013-02-22 18:25:04 (422 MB/s) - `userlogin!default.action;jsessionid=191ud808wgqik101mmdsvq2yw4@os_destination=%2FupdateAndBuild.action%3FbuildKey=TESTA-TSTA' saved [10073]
{code}

This is happening on Bamboo 4.4.x and is not replicable on older versions such as 4.3.x

*Workaround*
Append authentication credentials to the repository scripts os_authtype=basic&os_username=your_username&os_password=blah. Therefore something like this should work wget --timeout=10 -t1 http://localhost:10440/bamboo44/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey=TESTA-TSTA?os_authtype=basic&os_username=your_username&os_password=blah
fields.summary: Repository trigger when changes are committed does not work if anonymous access has been revoked
When SVN repository provides non-trimmed user names there are exceptions while saving BuildResult

fields.description:
( slightly different from BAM-9316 )

I'd like to be able to retrieve via the REST Api information on the plan's dependencies (manually set and auto generated), repository path and url to the build's log file.
fields.summary: REST Api for exposing plan configuration

fields.description:
The Maven Dependencies Processor (task) is pretty good at generating a list of Bamboo plan dependencies.  The fly in the ointment is that the available dependency build triggers only go up the chain, not down.

For example, given a chain consisting of:

  com.example.lib.core          COREBUILD
  com.example.lib.coolstuff     COOLBUILD  (depends on lib.core)
  com.example.lib.niftystuff    NIFTYBUILD (depends on lib.core and coolstuff)
  com.example.lib.moneystuff    MONEYBUILD (depends on lib.core)
  com.example.srv.happysrv      HAPPYBUILD (depends on lib.coolstuff, niftystuff and moneystuff)

If there's a change in the repository to niftystuff, I have the option to delay the building of NIFTYBUILD until its parents, COREBUILD and COOLBUILD, have completed building of any unbuilt changes.  This ensures that NIFTYBUILD is extra nifty by incorporating any pending changes from the libraries that it depends on (lib.core and coolstuff).

What I don't have is the additional option of having Bamboo complete the NIFTYBUILD based on the commit, and based on the dependency chain generated by the Maven Dependencies Processor, trigger the dependent/child HAPPYBUILD.  Even though one of its component libraries has changed, my normally happy server doesn't get rebuilt automatically unless I go into the manual dependency definition for each of its dependencies (COOLBUILD, NIFTYBUILD, MONEYBUILD), and add HAPPYBUILD as a child dependency.
fields.summary: Trigger builds for downstream maven dependency chain

fields.description:

The bug affecting Stash is rather hard to reproduce - AFAICT, it doesn't affect Bamboo.

fields.description:
I noticed the Global Audit log captures the scheduled backup last run time such as : 

SYSTEM    scheduleBackupConfiguration.lastRanDate 	1360394024868    1360998495172

This seems to capture the datetime the scheduled backup just ran and the previous time it ran. It would be nice if the current/last datetime the Build Expiry ran was captured in the same way.
fields.summary: Global Audit Log Should Log Build Expiry Run Date and time

fields.description: It would be nice if the REST API included the ability to retrieve the entire Plan Audit Log for a specified Plan key. In many cases there might be strict compliance/security/regulatory requirements (U.S. Export Control, HIPPA, U.S> FDA, etc) where the product being developed and built using Bamboo needs to have strict historical logging on plan configuration, settings, changes, etc. having a REST API so external security systems can retrieve the detailed audit log for a Plan would be useful.
fields.summary: REST API for Plan Audit Log

fields.description:
When a Plan is run manually it obviously logs who triggered it in the build result summary/history, but also there is a MetaData tab that contains the property "ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName" with a value of the user who triggered it.

If a Plan contains a Stage that is marked MANUAL then when that Plan is triggered in a non-manual way, say single daily build, VCS polling, or cron expression the plan runs, pauses at the Manual Stage, and waits for someone to continue the paused Manual Stage. This is a MANUAL action a user must take, thus the person who performed the action should get logged, but it does not, plus the ManualBuildTriggerReason.userName property doesn't get created/logged even though the Manual Stage was manually continued by userX. Whether it is that property or another one it seems the user who continues the Manual Stage should get logged somehow.
fields.summary: Logging Who Triggered a Manual Stage

fields.description:
When viewing the Recent History for a plan I can see my last dozen or so builds, the reason it triggered (manual, scheduled, etc), the time it took and tests if any.

On that screen if I have a plan with multiple stages if I manualy run the plan the trigger reason lists (Manual Build by Adam Myatt) as expected. If my plan is set to a single daily build or cron expression and it triggers, upon completion the history shows the trigger reason as Scheduled Build - as expected.

However if I have a plan scheduled to run, if that Plan has a Manual Stage anywhere in it, the after the plan stages all run (and someone manually clicks to continue the Manual Stage) the recent history shows that the build trigger reason was "Manual Build". This seems buggy or incorrect. The plan in question was ONLY triggered because of a scheduled trigger (or even polling VCS changes trigger). I realize because it has a Manual Stage somewhere in it that counts as a manual step, but the trigger reason description in the history should NOT say "Manual Build", but Scheduled or whatever was the actual reason. It seems like it is inheriting the Manual status of the Manual Stage.
fields.summary: Build History Trigger Reasons

fields.description:
deleting the files out from under a perforce client creates havoc in the build process.

If you are going to do this then you must follow it by a force sync of the work area.

In addition, our projects require a bootstrap process, one time setup.  So I NEVER want Bamboo to clean the directories.

I need an option that will prevent Bamboo from every cleaning the working directory.
fields.summary: Have an option to NEVER clean the working directory

fields.description:
As a user of Perforce, I don't want Bamboo to ever "clean" the build area.
All it does is mess up the environment.  It might work if it understood it needed to do a force sync after deleting all the files (p4 sync -f ).  There was an option saying "don't manage my workspace" and  I have always selected it.  But Bamboo does not respect it.  For me this is critical and it is a bug.

For instance, if I move the plans to a new server, I will change the name of the workspace.  Bamboo will delete all the files, the build will fail.  I have to go on the server, do a force sync, re-run the bootstrapping process for our application, re-run the build.

There is no way to do this cleanly.
fields.summary: Bamboo cleans the workspace when I don't want Bamboo to manage my workspace

fields.description: Starting from JIRA 5.x and Bamboo 4.3 we introduced the option to add  2-Legged OAuth requests. This has not been documented in our configuring application links page yet. Personally I have not seen any much difference. It will be nice if you could add a note section to explain the benefit or impact of choosing that option.
fields.summary: Document the impact or effect of choosing the 2-legged OAUTH option when configuring application links

fields.description:
The format of internal file that tracks what Bamboo workspace contains changed, which causes bamboo to think that repository definition has changed and that it should clear the existing content.

Edit: we should never clear directories that are not managed by Bamboo (e.g. Perforce unmanaged worspace)
fields.summary: Upgrade to 4.4 causes undesired clearing of workspace.

fields.description:
*Problem:*

Currently Clover tab is displayed on:
 * Plan Summary - yes
 * Build Summary - no
 * Job Summary - yes

It's misleading for end-users that they see stats on Plan Summary and have the link to Clover report from the BUILD, but when they go to the Build Summary they don't see Clover tab. 

*Suggested improvement:*

1. Add Clover tab on the Build Summary page if:
 * there is at least one Job with Clover configured (manual or automatic integration) and
 * there is at least one "Clover Report" artifact or clover.xml file available

2. What to display on this Clover tab (in the following priority):
 * if there is exactly one "Clover Report" artifact in some Job (and there are no clover.xml files in other Jobs) -> display Clover Report (HTML) exactly as it's presented on a Job Summary page; 
 * otherwise if there is exactly one clover.xml file in some Job -> display Clover Statistics (XML) exactly as it's presented on a Job Summary page
 * otherwise display a message like "Several Clover reports found. Choose: " and a list of "Job name + hyperlink to Job Summary / Clover tab"

*Out of scope:*

Merging of Clover databases from multiple jobs and generating of single consolidated report.
fields.summary: Add Clover tab for Build Summary page

fields.description:
The CommentManager interface and CommentManagerImpl class provide basic capabilities like querying all comments by user or by plan. When building bamboo plugins I have come across multiple use cases where, as an administrative user, it was be useful to search, view, or see ALL comments, regardless of user or plan they are associated with. 

There doesn't seem to be an easy way to get all comments without iterating through all plan's build results and using ResultSummaryManager or CommentManageImpl to get the actual comments. 

Ideally what is needed is the rough equivalent of running this type of query directly against the database : 

select * from user_comments

or at least "select content from user_comments order by created_date desc" (to get all the latest comments), and similar queries.
fields.summary: Improve CommentManagerImpl class in API to Retrieve All Comments

fields.description:
The atlassian connector plugin for IntelliJ idea is a phenomenal way to keep up with the tests being run in your code as you develop. I use it all the time.

We have just moved to an automatically detected plan branches configuration on bamboo, which enables even more automated testing, but now the plugin doesn't show me the branches that are being tested. 

Could there be support for plan branches in the IntelliJ plugin? Better yet, could it be branch based, instead of plan based? (meaning, I would like to click on a branch and see all the test plans being run on it). This is the frequent use-case.
fields.summary: IntelliJ plugin does not support plan branches

fields.description:
Add node capabilities for current version:
* Node.js 0.8 -> 0.8.21 (current latest stable)

Future versions to add will look something like:
* Node.js 1.0 -> 1.0.x
* Node.js 1.2 -> 1.2.x

Need to ensure npm is available and working.

Docs:
* [https://github.com/joyent/node/wiki/Installing-Node.js-via-package-manager]
fields.summary: Add Node.js to Elastic Bamboo

fields.description:
Despite being able to move and grab tasks within a job, you can't drag and drop them to another job.  This would be useful to have since refactoring is always a part of the development process.  

As a corollary to this request, it would be really useful if we could create easy to recycle custom Task libraries.
fields.summary: Tasks should be movable between jobs.

fields.description:
Possibly covered by, or at least related to BAM-12232, we've begun to encounter situations in which branch plans may differ in their capability requirements: specifically, the situation I'm thinking of is where a release branch has been built using, say, JDK 1.6, but we're moving the techstack from 1.6 to 1.7; in this case, we might want to move most of the agents to the 1.7 capability, but keep an agent that only advertises 1.6 capabilities to ensure that hotfixes can continue to be built until we're fully able to confirm the ability of an agent to switch between 1.6 and 1.7.

This would apply to testing that requires specific environments, etc. The ability to specify a per-branch-plan capability requirement would require more setup on our end, but would guarantee the stability of branch builds in specific environments without having to promote a branch-plan to the top level to specify its available agents.
fields.summary: Per-branch-plan capability requirements

fields.description:
This may be moot in that the standard bamboo.sh is designed to run on all *nix platforms, but according to the LSB standard at http://refspecs.linuxbase.org/LSB_3.1.1/LSB-Core-generic/LSB-Core-generic/iniscrptact.html the appropriate response code for status() should be 3 if the application isn't running.

Once I finish testing changes, I'll attach the version of the script we're using in case it provides a useful template.
fields.summary: Per LSB specs, bamboo.sh status() should return 3 not 1 if Bamboo isn't running

Setting build-dir to ephemeral drive on EC2 OnDemand agent breaks home directory for SSH keys when cloning submodules

fields.description:
Hi I have build plan setup in Bamboo as follows:

Stage 1:
  Job: Clean History
  Job: Clean Repository
  Job: Clean Cache
Stage 2:
  Job: Build and Test
Stage 3: 
  Job: Report Results

Now the same plan is run for multiple branches in the GIT repository. Since we have only single clean environment we have only single Agent running all jobs sequentially. But what I see is when multiple checkin happen the Stages across multiple branches get mixed up, thus resulting in the following run sequence where stages of one branch get mixed with stages of other branch.

Branch 1, executes Stage 1
Branch 2, executes Stage 1
Branch 1, executes Stage 2
Branch 2, executes Stage 2
Branch 1, executes Stage 3
Branch 2, executes Stage 3

With this work flow, the last job will definitely fail as it will never get a clean environment. Not sure if this is a bug, but I believe a build plan run should be atomic and isolated and is currently not the case.
fields.summary: Add option in Bamboo for locking agent for the complete plan build.
